Mathematical Notation Standards for DIP-SMC-PSO DocumentationÂ¶

This document provides standards and examples for mathematical notation in the DIP-SMC-PSO project documentation.

1. Unicode Mathematical SymbolsÂ¶

1.1 Greek Letters (Preferred)Â¶

  • Use Unicode Greek letters: Î¸â‚, Î¸â‚‚, Î»â‚, Î»â‚‚, Ï‰, Ï†

  • Not ASCII approximations: theta1, theta2, lambda1, lambda2

1.2 Mathematical OperatorsÂ¶

  • Integral: âˆ«â‚€áµ€ (not integral from 0 to T)

  • Partial derivative: âˆ‚f/âˆ‚x (not df/dx)

  • Nabla operator: âˆ‡f (not grad f)

  • Summation: âˆ‘áµ¢â‚Œâ‚â¿ (not sum from i=1 to n)

1.3 Subscripts and SuperscriptsÂ¶

  • Position subscripts: xâ‚, xâ‚‚, xâ‚ƒ

  • Time derivatives: Î¸Ì‡â‚, Î¸Ìˆâ‚ (preferred) or Î¸â‚_dot, Î¸â‚_ddot

  • Powers: xÂ² (preferred) or x^2

2. Control Theory Notation StandardsÂ¶

2.1 Sliding Mode ControlÂ¶

"""
Classical SMC sliding surface definition:

s = Î»â‚eâ‚ + Î»â‚‚eâ‚‚ + Ä—â‚ + Ä—â‚‚

where:
- eâ‚ = Î¸â‚ - Î¸â‚áµˆ (angular position error for pendulum 1)
- eâ‚‚ = Î¸â‚‚ - Î¸â‚‚áµˆ (angular position error for pendulum 2)
- Ä—â‚ = Î¸Ì‡â‚ - Î¸Ì‡â‚áµˆ (angular velocity error for pendulum 1)
- Ä—â‚‚ = Î¸Ì‡â‚‚ - Î¸Ì‡â‚‚áµˆ (angular velocity error for pendulum 2)
- Î»â‚, Î»â‚‚ > 0 (sliding surface gains for Hurwitz stability)

Stability Condition:
For exponential convergence to the sliding surface, require:
Î»â‚, Î»â‚‚ > 0 ensuring the characteristic polynomial sÂ² + Î»â‚‚s + Î»â‚ = 0
has roots in the left half-plane.
"""

2.2 Lyapunov Function DocumentationÂ¶

"""
Lyapunov stability analysis for SMC reaching condition:

V(s) = Â½sÂ²

Taking the time derivative along system trajectories:
VÌ‡(s) = sÂ·á¹¡ = sÂ·(Î»â‚Ä—â‚ + Î»â‚‚Ä—â‚‚ + Ã«â‚ + Ã«â‚‚)

For the reaching condition VÌ‡ < 0 when s â‰  0, the switching gain K must satisfy:
K > |f_eq(x)| + Î´

where f_eq is the equivalent control and Î´ > 0 accounts for uncertainties.
"""

2.3 Super-Twisting AlgorithmÂ¶

"""
Second-order sliding mode (Super-Twisting) control law:

u = uâ‚ + uâ‚‚

where:
uâ‚ = -Î±|s|^(1/2)sign(s)
uâ‚‚ = âˆ«â‚€áµ—(-Î² sign(s))dÏ„

Parameters Î±, Î² > 0 must satisfy the convergence condition:
Î± > âˆš(2L), Î² > Î±Â²/(2(Î±-âˆš(2L)))

where L is the Lipschitz constant of the uncertainty.
"""

3. Optimization Theory NotationÂ¶

3.1 PSO DynamicsÂ¶

"""
Particle Swarm Optimization update equations:

váµ¢áµ—âºÂ¹ = wÂ·váµ¢áµ— + câ‚râ‚(páµ¢ - xáµ¢áµ—) + câ‚‚râ‚‚(g - xáµ¢áµ—)
xáµ¢áµ—âºÂ¹ = xáµ¢áµ— + váµ¢áµ—âºÂ¹

where:
- xáµ¢áµ— âˆˆ â„â¿: position of particle i at iteration t
- váµ¢áµ— âˆˆ â„â¿: velocity of particle i at iteration t
- páµ¢ âˆˆ â„â¿: personal best position of particle i
- g âˆˆ â„â¿: global best position
- w âˆˆ [0,1]: inertia weight
- câ‚, câ‚‚ > 0: acceleration coefficients
- râ‚, râ‚‚ ~ U(0,1): random variables

Convergence requires: w < 1 and câ‚ + câ‚‚ < 4(1 + w)
"""

3.2 Cost Function DefinitionÂ¶

"""
Multi-objective cost function for controller optimization:

J(k) = wâ‚Â·ISE(k) + wâ‚‚Â·ITAE(k) + wâ‚ƒÂ·U_max(k) + wâ‚„Â·Penalty(k)

where:
- ISE(k) = âˆ«â‚€áµ€ â€–e(t,k)â€–Â² dt (Integral Squared Error)
- ITAE(k) = âˆ«â‚€áµ€ tÂ·â€–e(t,k)â€–â‚ dt (Integral Time Absolute Error)
- U_max(k) = max_{tâˆˆ[0,T]} |u(t,k)| (Control effort penalty)
- Penalty(k): Instability penalty (â†’ âˆ if unstable)
- wáµ¢ â‰¥ 0: weighting factors with âˆ‘wáµ¢ = 1
"""

4. Performance Metrics NotationÂ¶

4.1 Standard Control MetricsÂ¶

"""
Performance Metrics for Control Systems:

1. Integral Squared Error (ISE):
   ISE = âˆ«â‚€áµ€ â€–e(t)â€–Â² dt

2. Integral Time Absolute Error (ITAE):
   ITAE = âˆ«â‚€áµ€ tÂ·â€–e(t)â€–â‚ dt

3. Integral Absolute Error (IAE):
   IAE = âˆ«â‚€áµ€ â€–e(t)â€–â‚ dt

4. Root Mean Square Error (RMSE):
   RMSE = âˆš(1/T âˆ«â‚€áµ€ â€–e(t)â€–Â² dt)

5. Maximum Overshoot:
   OS = max(x(t)) - x_final / x_final Ã— 100%

6. Settling Time (2% criterion):
   t_s = inf{t > 0 : |x(Ï„) - x_final| â‰¤ 0.02|x_final| âˆ€Ï„ â‰¥ t}
"""

5. Statistical Analysis NotationÂ¶

5.1 Monte Carlo ValidationÂ¶

"""
Monte Carlo Uncertainty Quantification:

Given N independent samples {Jâ‚, Jâ‚‚, ..., Jâ‚™} of the cost function:

Sample Mean: Î¼Ì‚ = 1/N âˆ‘áµ¢â‚Œâ‚á´º Jáµ¢

Sample Variance: ÏƒÌ‚Â² = 1/(N-1) âˆ‘áµ¢â‚Œâ‚á´º (Jáµ¢ - Î¼Ì‚)Â²

Confidence Interval (Î± = 0.05):
CIâ‚€.â‚‰â‚… = Î¼Ì‚ Â± t_{N-1,Î±/2} Â· ÏƒÌ‚/âˆšN

where t_{N-1,Î±/2} is the (1-Î±/2) quantile of the t-distribution with N-1 degrees of freedom.
"""

5.2 Hypothesis TestingÂ¶

"""
Welch's t-test for comparing controller performance:

Hâ‚€: Î¼â‚ = Î¼â‚‚ (no difference in mean performance)
Hâ‚: Î¼â‚ â‰  Î¼â‚‚ (significant difference in performance)

Test Statistic:
t = (xÌ„â‚ - xÌ„â‚‚) / âˆš(sâ‚Â²/nâ‚ + sâ‚‚Â²/nâ‚‚)

Degrees of Freedom (Welch-Satterthwaite):
Î½ = (sâ‚Â²/nâ‚ + sâ‚‚Â²/nâ‚‚)Â² / ((sâ‚Â²/nâ‚)Â²/(nâ‚-1) + (sâ‚‚Â²/nâ‚‚)Â²/(nâ‚‚-1))

Reject Hâ‚€ if |t| > t_{Î½,Î±/2} where Î± is the significance level.
"""

6. LaTeX Integration GuidelinesÂ¶

6.1 Sphinx DocumentationÂ¶

For Sphinx-generated documentation, use LaTeX math blocks:

.. math::
   s = \lambda_1 e_1 + \lambda_2 e_2 + \dot{e}_1 + \dot{e}_2

   \text{where } e_i = \theta_i - \theta_i^d

6.2 Jupyter NotebooksÂ¶

For interactive documentation in notebooks:

from IPython.display import Math, display

display(Math(r's = \lambda_1 e_1 + \lambda_2 e_2 + \dot{e}_1 + \dot{e}_2'))

7. Docstring ExamplesÂ¶

7.1 Function Documentation with MathÂ¶

def compute_sliding_surface(self, state: np.ndarray, target: np.ndarray) -> float:
    """Compute the sliding surface value for classical SMC.

    The sliding surface is defined as:
    s = Î»â‚eâ‚ + Î»â‚‚eâ‚‚ + Ä—â‚ + Ä—â‚‚

    where:
    - eâ‚, eâ‚‚: position errors for pendulum 1 and 2
    - Ä—â‚, Ä—â‚‚: velocity errors for pendulum 1 and 2
    - Î»â‚, Î»â‚‚: sliding surface gains (must be positive)

    Mathematical Background:
    The sliding surface design ensures that once the system reaches
    the surface (s=0), it will remain on the surface and converge
    to the desired equilibrium point in finite time.

    Parameters
    ----------
    state : np.ndarray, shape (6,)
        Current system state [Î¸â‚, Î¸â‚‚, x, Î¸Ì‡â‚, Î¸Ì‡â‚‚, áº‹]
    target : np.ndarray, shape (6,)
        Target state (typically upright equilibrium [0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0])

    Returns
    -------
    float
        Sliding surface value. System is on sliding surface when s = 0.

    References
    ----------
    .. [1] Utkin, V. "Sliding Modes in Control and Optimization", 1992
    .. [2] Edwards, C. "Sliding Mode Control: Theory and Applications", 1998
    """

7.2 Class Documentation with TheoryÂ¶

class ClassicalSMC:
    """Classical Sliding Mode Controller for double-inverted pendulum.

    Implements the classical SMC algorithm with boundary layer for chattering
    reduction. The control law consists of equivalent control and switching
    control components:

    u = u_eq + u_sw

    where:
    - u_eq: Equivalent control (model-based feedforward)
    - u_sw: Switching control (robust feedback)

    The sliding surface is designed as:
    s = Î»â‚eâ‚ + Î»â‚‚eâ‚‚ + Ä—â‚ + Ä—â‚‚

    Stability is guaranteed when Î»â‚, Î»â‚‚ > 0, ensuring the characteristic
    polynomial sÂ² + Î»â‚‚s + Î»â‚ = 0 has stable roots.

    Parameters
    ----------
    gains : List[float]
        Controller gains [kâ‚, kâ‚‚, Î»â‚, Î»â‚‚, K, k_d] where:
        - kâ‚, kâ‚‚: Position feedback gains
        - Î»â‚, Î»â‚‚: Sliding surface gains
        - K: Switching gain
        - k_d: Derivative gain
    max_force : float
        Maximum control force (saturation limit)
    boundary_layer : float
        Boundary layer thickness for chattering reduction

    Attributes
    ----------
    n_gains : int
        Number of controller gains (6 for classical SMC)

    Examples
    --------
    >>> controller = ClassicalSMC(
    ...     gains=[10.0, 5.0, 8.0, 3.0, 15.0, 2.0],
    ...     max_force=100.0,
    ...     boundary_layer=0.01
    ... )
    >>> state = np.array([0.1, 0.05, 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 0.0])
    >>> result = controller.compute_control(state, None, {})
    >>> print(f"Control output: {result['u']:.4f}")
    """

8. Validation and Quality AssuranceÂ¶

8.1 Mathematical Accuracy ChecklistÂ¶

  • All Greek letters use Unicode symbols

  • Subscripts and superscripts properly formatted

  • Mathematical operators use standard Unicode symbols

  • Equations are mathematically correct and consistent

  • Units are specified where applicable

  • Stability conditions are properly documented

  • References to literature are accurate

8.2 Documentation Review ProcessÂ¶

  1. Technical Review: Verify mathematical accuracy

  2. Consistency Check: Ensure notation consistency across modules

  3. Literature Validation: Verify references and citations

  4. User Testing: Validate documentation clarity with target audience

  5. Rendering Verification: Check mathematical notation displays correctly

This standard ensures consistent, professional mathematical documentation throughout the DIP-SMC-PSO project.
